blast.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a sudden strong movement of wind or air
blast.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: A blast of cold air swept through the hut.
blast.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: an explosion, or the very strong movement of air that it causes
blast.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: A bomb blast completely destroyed the building.
Thirty-six people died in the blast.
blast.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a sudden very loud noise, especially one made by a whistle or horn
blast.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: The station master gave a blast on his whistle and we were off.
blast.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: a sudden strong expression of a powerful emotion
blast.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: She was totally unprepared for the blast of criticism she received.
blast.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to damage or destroy something, or to injure or kill someone, using a gun or a bomb
blast.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The first shot missed and blasted a hole in the far wall.
The plane was blasted out of the sky by a terrorist bomb.
She blasted her husband with a shotgun because he was having an affair.
blast.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to break something into pieces using explosives, especially in order to build something such as a road
blast.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: A 1.5 km tunnel was blasted through the mountain.
The road will have to be blasted out of solid rock.
Railway workers had blasted through the mountains 90 years before.
blast.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to produce a lot of loud noise, especially music
blast.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: He was woken by the radio alarm clock blasting out rock music.
Dance music blasted from the stereo.
blast.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: to criticize someone or something very strongly – used especially in news reports
blast.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: Union leaders blasted the government for failing to tackle the jobs crisis.
blast.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: to hit or kick a ball very hard
blast.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: With six minutes remaining, he blasted the ball through the Coleraine defences for his 19th goal of the season.
blast.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: if air or water is blasted somewhere, or if it blasts somewhere, it moves there with great force
blast.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: The wind ripped through the trees and blasted a curtain of rain up the meadow.
Icy winds and driving snow blasted through the pine trees.
blast.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: to beat another team very easily
blast.translation[1].definitions[6].exam: The Seahawks were blasted 35–14 by the Broncos.
blast.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: used when you are very annoyed about something
blast.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Oh blast! I’ve forgotten my key.
